coredata.dc:title: Shortest paths in semi-directed circulant graphs Najkrajše poti v delno usmerjenih krožnih grafih

abstract.ce:para: A k-circulant graph G(n; ±h1, . . . , ±h k) is an undirected graph where the node set is ℤn = {0,1, . . . , n - 1} and the edge set is the union of sets of unordered pairs Ei = {(u, u + sign(i) * h\i\ (mod n))\u ∈ ℤn}, for i ∈{ - k,. . . . - 1, 1, . . . , k}. Circulant graphs have been extensively studied as topologies for computer networks and distributed memory multiprocessor systems [1, 2, 3, 4, 9, 10]. Let I k = {- k, . . . , - 1, 1, . . . , k}. For every i ∈ I k, we define a semi-directed k-circulant graph Gi(n; ± h1, . . . , ± hk) as a graph with the node set V = ℤn and the edge set E = ∪i∈I-{j}E j. The shortest path in a semi-directed circulant graph is called restricted shortest path (RSP) [5]. The RSPs are used to perform an efficient dynamic two-terminal routing in undirected circulant graphs. In this paper we introduce three algorithms for calculating the restricted shortest paths: script O sign(log n) algorithm for calculating the restricted shortest paths in 2-circulant graphs (algorithm I), script O sing(nk) algorithm for calculating the restricted shortest paths in k-circulant graphs (algorithm II), and script O sign(log n) algorithm for calculating approximations for the restricted shortest paths in k-circulant graphs (algorithm III). We also estimate the quallity of algorithm III by comparing it with the resuts given by the algorithm II.
